The 'Peace Mothers' (Turkish= BarÄ±Å Anneleri) is a women's civil rights movement
in Turkey, which aims to promote peace between Turkey's different ethnic groups
through non-violent means.

The Peace Mothers dates from 1999. A member of the founding Assembly explained "
We had come together to say that the dirty war should come to an end and that
there should be peace among Turks and Kurds." {{cite web |title= Kurdish
and Turkish Mothers: Letâs Build Peace Together! |publisher= International
Fellowship of Reconciliation |date=2007-05-24 |url= http://www.ifor.org/WPP/Articles/May24-
2007OK.pdf |accessdate=2009-08-20}} Many of the women involved have lost a
close relative in the KurdishâTurkish conflict. In the words of TÃ¼rkiye Bozkurt
" In 1999 we came together as mothers, whose children were either in the
mountains, in prisons or had lost their lives in the war." {{cite web
|title= International Women's Day for Peace and Disarmament |publisher=
International Peace Bureau |year=2007 |url= http://www.ipb.org/i/pdf-files/May_24-
2007_Int_Womens_Day_for_Peace_and_Disarmament.pdf |accessdate=2009-08-20}}
They are based in Istanbul and Diyarbakir. {{cite web |title=
Delegationsbericht der Newroz-Delegation 2008 aus MÃ¼nchen, Berlin und NRW
|publisher= Deutsch-Kurdischen Gesellschaft |year=2008 |url= http://www.dkg-muenchen.de/DKG%20Aktuell-
Dateien/DelegationsberichtNewroz.html |accessdate=2009-08-20}} 

They have been frequently in the news for their protests and court cases. In
2000, Amnesty International reported a delegation of Peace Mothers had allegedly
been tortured and ill-treated, after they travelled to neighbouring Iraq to try
to mediate between the two sides in the civil conflict in the Kurdish region in
North Iraq. The lawyer who defended them, Eren Keskin, was later put on trial
for having insulted the army after her description of the alleged torture of the
Peace Mothers was published in a newspaper. {{cite web |title= Memorandum
from Amnesty International UK |publisher= Amnesty International |year=2002
|month=January |url= http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200102/cmselect-
/cmfaff/606/2021209.htm |accessdate=2009-08-20}} {{cite web |title=
Turkey: Torture/ill-treatment |publisher= Amnesty International |date=2000-10-19
|month=January |url= http://www.amnesty.org.ru/library/Index/ENGEUR440552000?open&of=ENG-
TUR |accessdate=2009-08-20}} 

In June 2006, Peace Mother activists Muyesser Gunes and Sakine Arat were
sentenced to 1 year jail each and 600 YTL in Ankara 4th Criminal Court on a
charge of praising a separatist organisation and its leader, after they had
visited the General Staff headquarters on 22 August 2005 to present their case.
The sentence was later commuted to 10 months. {{cite web |title= Jail
sentence to Peace Mothers |publisher= Karawane |date=2006-06-03 |url=
http://thecaravan.org/node/757 |accessdate=2009-08-20}}

In August 2009 a group of Peace Mothers organised a peace march from Diyarbakir
and Ankara and held a sit-in protest near the Turkish General Staff headquarters
in Ankara. {{cite web |title= Pro-peace mothers march from Diyarbekir to
Ankara |publisher= AK News |date=2009-08-11
|url=http://www.aknews.com/en/aknews/4/62145 |accessdate=2009-08-20}}
